_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Trident Seafoods Corporation Sand Point shore plant employs up to 502 people on a seasonal basis.  The facility processes primarily Cod, Pollock, Salmon, crab, Halibut and other species of Alaskan Seafood.    Anhydrous ammonia in excess of the thresh hold limit of 10,000 pounds is used to freeze and store product and is subject the Process Safety Management (PSM) program developed by OSHA and the Risk Management Program (RMP) from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to operate and maintain their refrigeration system.  The RMP is submitted to the EPA to meet the requirements of Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, codified in the Code of Federal Regulation (CFR) Title 40 Part 68.

There is a management system that designates the responsibility of each section of the RMP to a specific person.  Most sections of the Risk Management Plan are reviewed yearly, revised and updated.  Every five years a process hazard analysis is completed or revalidated for the entire system.  A written follow up report is generated, and recommendations documented.  Every three years a compliance audit is performed, and program components are reviewed in order to examine and improve our program. Document management for the PSM program is done through SharePoint and allows for enhanced employee participation and communication.  



Accidental Release Prevention Program

The ammonia system uses 40,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in cold storage, chillers, a brine freezer, blast freezers, plate freezers and in the operation of ice making machines.  A worse case and alternate worst case scenario have been studied and details the effects of an ammonia release.  This modeling is shared with employees and is useful in communicating what the potential effects would be for alternate and worse case scenarios.

The prevention program, complying with 29 CFR 1910.119, fosters employ

ee participation.  Training is an essential part of every section of the PSM/RMP program.  Knowledge of the program begins with an understanding of the components and equipment.  This collected data is compiled and presented in the Process Safety information section.   Standard operating procedures both detail and instruct process operation and maintenance procedures.  Any changes are documented to insure any modification is correctly designed, and properly installed by qualified contractors and maintenance persons.  Possible hazards and safety recommendations are reviewed and considered.  Hot work permits are used to insure safe operation where welding, cutting, or hot work is performed.  The mechanical integrity of the system is methodically inspected and tested for operation to insure safe operation.  The operation of the plant prevention program follows guidelines and standards set forth by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration, ANSI/IIAR-2, ASHRAE Standard 15, and ASME B-31 as well as recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

Five Year Accident History (40 CFR 68.42)

There has been one reportable accident involving ammonia at the Trident Seafoods Corp. Sandpoint, Alaska facility during the last five years. This incident occurred on 8/26/2016 when 2 employees needed treatment for an incident involving a plate freezer. Release amount was estimated to be approximately 39 pounds. 

 

Emergency Response Plan

Trident Seafoods Sand Point, Alaska has a written Emergency Response Plan.  Annual HAZWOPER refresher training is conducted for responders.  Emergency evacuation and response training drills are held periodically during the year to acquaint seasonal employees with emergency response procedures and to practice the emergency response team.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Trident Seafoods is constantly improving its Safety program.  Monthly safety meetings are held in most months of the year.  Representatives from each d

epartment attend.  The plant manager and plant safety officer attend community emergency planning meetings to insure a full understanding of community hazards and to prepare for timely emergency response. 

PSM meetings are conducted on a monthly basis with corporate engineering, safety and environmental departments to review refrigeration projects and discuss regulatory compliance and safety requirements and needs for the plant
